sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• While Clodsire is lacking in physical bulk compared to Dondozo and Skeledirge, it makes up for it in having a fantastic support movepool.

  • Yawn is very effective at forcing switches, which is especially dangerous if Stealth Rock is set up.

  • Poison Jab is Clodsire's best move against Tera Fairy Rotom-W, which is an especially important target when using Water Absorb.

  • Protect, in addition to benefiting from Leftovers, pairs well with Yawn.

  • Body Press isn't particularly strong, but it does prevent Clodsire from being totally walled by Tera Steel Hydreigon if using a physically defensive spread.

  • Black Sludge may seem appealing, but it punishes Clodsire for Terastalliizing unless it becomes Tera Poison, so Leftovers is preferred unless Leftovers is already on something else.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Clodsire no longer has to worry about Earthquake or Fissure.

  • Steel: A Steel Tera type allows Clodsire to take on powerful Dragon-type attacks, without the worry of Gholdengo dealing massive damage.

  • Poison: With Tera Poison, Clodsire not only becomes a better check to Grass- and Water-types such as Meowscarda and Rotom-W, but it can also safely run Black Sludge to punish users of Trick.

  • Fairy: A Fairy Tera type will stop powerful Dragon-type attacks cold without making Clodsire weak to Earthquake, but it comes at the cost of compromising its ability to check Gholdengo.

  • Dark: Espathra's Stored Power is a big issue for Clodsire, so Tera Dark can flip the tables on it.

Abilities

  • Unaware: If you're planning to use Clodsire to its fullest defensive potential, Unaware is the best bet against setup foes.

  • Water Absorb: Water Absorb sacrifices overall defensive potential in exchange for being able to wall Rotom-W without needing to Terastallize. If setting up Stealth Rock is important, this can be worth it.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Spe with Careful: Maximizing Special Defense is Clodsire's best hope for handling powerful special attackers such as Choice Specs Hydreigon.

  • 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Spe with Impish: Clodsire's Defense may be mediocre, but with maximum investment, it can pull stunts such as usually avoiding a 2HKO from Jolly Dragonite's Outrage with Leftovers.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: With huge HP and Special Defense stats, Clodsire makes use of Ice Scales to serve as a strong special wall, or it can instead function as a versatile support Pokemon that utilizes Prankster to cripple opposing Pokemon and deter setup. Toxic allows Clodsire to wear down opposing walls, while Toxic Spikes punishes switching and and cripples pivoting foes; Poison Jab is a final option to hit Noivern and still spread status. Spikes and Stealth Rock are both good options for additional entry hazards, with Spikes damage stacking with Toxic Spikes poison and Stealth Rock punishing Flying-types switching into Clodsire. Haze is another option that lets Clodsire stop threatening setup sweepers like Volcarona, though it should almost always be run on Prankster variants. Frail offensive teammates like Iron Bundle and Iron Valiant appreciate Clodsire's ability to soak up strong special attacks, and Clodsire appreciates them taking out foes it's too passive to handle on its own. Clodsire also has below average Defense, so it benefits from being paired with physically defensive teammates like Fur Coat Corviknight and Avalugg.

vgc2023.overview:
• Farigiraf is currently one of the bulkiest Trick Room setters in the meta. Its ability, Armor Tail, prevents its teammates from succumbing to priority moves, making it difficult to prevent Farigiraf from setting Trick Room.

  • Hariyama, Amoonguss, and Kingambit are good partners for Farigiraf. Hariyama and Farigiraf both benefit from each other, as Fake Out allows Farigiraf to more consistently get up Trick Room, which enables Hariyama, as it thrives inside of Trick Room and checks Farigiraf's common counters. Amoonguss can redirect moves targeted at Farigiraf and Spore anything inside Trick Room to take them out of the game. Kingambit benefits from the Snarl that Farigiraf struggles against and plays well in Trick Room.

  • Choice Band Meowscarada and Hydreigon are the biggest checks to Farigiraf, as both threaten to OHKO it. Amoonguss is another check, as it can Spore Farigiraf before it manages to get Trick Room up. It also struggles against Imprison from Indeedee, Gallade, and opposing Farigiraf.

sets.name: Bulky Trick Room
sets.description:
• Hyper Voice is a decently strong Normal-type STAB move for Farigiraf to spread chip damage that softens up opponents for its allies. Psyshock tackles common Psychic-weak Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Gengar, whereas Dazzling Gleam improves its matchup into common checks like Meowscarada and Hydreigon. Helping Hand allows Farigiraf to supplement a harder hitting teammate's damage output. Imprison is used on fast offensive teams that would otherwise struggle against opposing Trick Room teams.

  • Safety Goggles provides an immunity to Spore from Amoonguss and Breloom, who would otherwise prevent Trick Room from going up with it. Sitrus Berry gives Farigiraf longevity with recovery. Colbur Berry allows Farigiraf to consistently get Trick Room up in the face of Meowscarada and Hydreigon.

  • For other notable items, Mental Herb prevents fast Taunt users like Talonflame from interrupting Farigiraf's Trick Room. Life Orb or Throat Spray are good options to improve Farigiraf's already decent damage output. Rocky Helmet can also be used for an answer to unsuspecting Maushold.

  • 180 EVs in HP allow Farigiraf to survive maximum HP Annihilape Final Gambit, and the defensive investment allows it to always survive Tera Steel Choice Specs Gholdengo Make It Rain and Focus Sash Meowscarada Knock Off.

  • Tera Fairy is more of a defensive Tera type, giving it a resistance to all the types that Farigiraf was previously weak to while gaining STAB on Dazzling Gleam. Tera Normal adds damage onto Hyper Voice and removes its Dark weakness.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
• Kingambit sets itself apart from most other Dark-types with its bulk and typing, which make it a reasonable check against Gholdengo that lack Focus Blast.

  • Guillotine makes Kingambit far more difficult to wall with foes such as Dondozo.

  • Brick Break is rather weak, but it helps against opposing Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Dark: A Dark Tera type makes Kingambit even harder to wall and removes its irritating Ground weakness.

  • Flying: This Tera type covers Kingambit's issues with Fighting- and Ground-type attacks very well.

  • Fairy: With a Fairy Tera type, Kingambit gains a resistance to Fighting and can still deal with Dragon-types, but it becomes vulnerable to Gholdengo.

Abilities

  • Supreme Overload: This is generally the more consistent ability since Intimidate foes are not very common.

  • Defiant: Defiant is still useful for punishing speed control options such as Rock Tomb, especially alongside Sucker Punch.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe: This simple spread maximizes bulk and power.

  • 108 HP / 252 Atk / 148 Spe: This EV spread has enough Speed to outspeed most Corviknight and Skeledirge, and it still has enough bulk to survive one unboosted Body Press from Corviknight. Since this is a fairly congested Speed range, feel free to move some Attack EVs to Speed.

Items

  • Black Glasses: While its boost to Dark-type attacks isn't as high as Life Orb's, Black Glasses is a better fit for Kingambit's bulk due to the lack of recoil.

  • Sitrus Berry: The burst of recovery helps Kingambit check Gholdengo better.

  • Assault Vest: Assault Vest makes Kingambit a better check against Gholdengo and Hydreigon.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit is a dangerous wallbreaker, owing to great base stats and Adaptability. After using Swords Dance, Kingambit threatens the entire tier, including incredibly bulky physical walls such as Fur Coat Corviknight and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster threats, such as Iron Bundle and Dragapult, making it difficult to check offensively. Life Orb provides the highest damage boost to Kingambit's attacks, notably ensuring a 2HKO on Fur Coat Corviknight; alternatively, Black Glasses provides a damage boost without digging into Kingambit's limited healthpool, while Leftovers allows Kingambit to reliably switch in on weaker attacks. Kingambit best fits on offense teams, which appreciate its massive damage output and can provide opportunities for it to switch in safely. Slow pivoting teammates, such as RegenVest Iron Treads and Ice Scales Corviknight, are recommended, as they can safely pivot Kingambit in and also clear entry hazards. 144 Speed EVs are used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight. Kingambit is incredibly threatened by Great Tusk and Iron Hands, as both can easily live even boosted hits and threaten to OHKO back, so teammates like Florges and Iron Valiant are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description: Rapid Spin, Knock Off, and great physical bulk make Great Tusk a fantastic utility spinner. It can check dangerous physical attackers such as Ceruledge, Slither Wing, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon and retaliate with its beefy Earthquake and Body Press. It matches up well against common entry hazard setters like Garganacl and Clodsire, and it threatens spinblockers with Knock Off; Knock Off also augments its teammates' entry hazards by removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Leftovers gives it much needed recovery—especially alongside Regenerator—but Heavy-Duty Boots prevents it from being overwhelmed by the entry hazards it must remove. Teammates such as Blissey and Slowking can cover opposing special attackers that target Great Tusk's lower Special Defense. In return, they appreciate Great Tusk dealing with physical attackers like opposing Great Tusk.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Great Tusk is a dangerous wallbreaker thanks to its high-powered STAB moves and either Mold Breaker to bypass Fur Coat or Stakeout for the reliable power against non-Fur Coat targets. Knock Off has no immunities, unlike both STAB options, and removes key items like Leftovers from Corviknight. Ice Spinner breaks through defensive Dragonite and Garchomp with a clean OHKO. Fast specially offensive pivots like Iron Bundle, Dragapult, and Noivern can bring Great Tusk in safely to pressure their specially defensive switch-ins like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Blissey. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Hands are also good options, as they can switch into faster threats like Iron Bundle and Iron Moth, respectively, which force Great Tusk out. Dragonite and Ceruledge appreciate Great Tusk wallbreaking early-game by threatening Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Garganacl, which lets them clean up late-game more easily.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Boomburst Scream Tail functions as a bulky utility option and a potentially powerful setup threat. With Boomburst, Scream Tail can topple many threats such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon, making it far less passive than most walls. Calm Mind lets it serve as a bulky wincon, while Flamethrower deters Steel-types like Gholdengo from switching in and Stealth Rock lets it make progress against foes it cannot threaten like Ice Scales Clodsire. Scream Tail's great matchup into common Dark-, Fighting-, and Dragon-types makes it a great partner for offensive teammates that struggle with those foes, like Iron Bundle, Garchomp, and Iron Treads. Scream Tail struggles with Poison- and Fire-types such as Clodsire and Volcarona, as well as Steel-types if it does not run Flamethrower, so teammates such as Iron Bundle and Iron Treads are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Defensive Scream Tail serves as an answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Iron Hands and Dragonite. Encore locks Pokemon into moves that they do not want to be locked into, such as Volcarona with Quiver Dance or Morning Sun, Blissey into Soft-Boiled, and Avalugg into Recover. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be ran if the team needs entry hazard support. Fur Coat is the most common ability, but Regenerator allows it to better check opposing pivots like Iron Hands; alternatively, Prankster Encore can be used to deter opposing setup attempts. Scream Tail serves as a defensive answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types, so Pokemon such as Blissey and Kingambit are appreciated. It is unable to check several common physical attackers like Ceruledge and Kingambit, so secondary physically defensive teammates like Regenerator Iron Hands are appreciated.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Normalize
sets.description: Normalize Flutter-Mane is a dangerous setup sweeper that requires specific counterplay to deal with. Entrainment + Normalize prevents foes from damaging Flutter Mane, with its Fairy typing giving it an immunity to the common Draco Plate Judgment. Quiver Dance increases damage output and allows Flutter Mane to outspeed and nullify would-be faster threats like Zacian-C. Taunt prevents defensive checks from PP stalling Flutter Mane and denies Glare; alternatively, Strength Sap provides Flutter Mane with longevity, allowing it to repeatedly switch into passive Pokemon. Pixie Plate lets Flutter Mane hit Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Arceus-Dark super effectively, whereas Spooky Plate lets it hit Imposter users and opposing Ghost-types harder. A Modest nature provides a power boost, while Timid can be used to outspeed positive natured Arceus formes to use Entrainment first. Flutter Mane struggles against bulky Magic Bounce and Good as Gold users, so strong wallbreakers such as Choice Band Zacian-C and Choice Specs Miraidon are good partners. Even with Normalize, Flutter Mane can still be statused by moves like Glare and Will-O-Wisp, so a Heal Bell user can be helpful. Flutter Mane also has poor physical bulk, so slow defensive pivots like Ting-Lu and RegenVest Hisuian Goodra are appreciated to bring Flutter Mane in safely while also providing Knock Off support to remove Ability Shield.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing’s massive Attack stat combined with STAB U-turn and First Impression allow it to be a great wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Earthquake is an option to bash Skeledirge whereas Flare Blitz is better into Corviknight and bulky Fighting resistant foes such as Scream Tail and Fur Coat Florges on non-Tinted Lens sets. Tinted Lens is useful for revenge killing Dragapult, Dragonite, and Volcarona with First Impression after minimal chip, Sword of Ruin provides the most power against neutral targets, and Oricalchum Pulse is recommended for Flare Blitz variants. Special wallbreaker partners such as Iron Bundle and Iron Moth break Fur Coat Pokemon that trouble Slither Wing and appreciate Slither Wings ability to break the Ice Scales walls they hate in return. Slither Wing loves being partnered with bulky pivots such as Chilly Reception Slowking, Corviknight, and Desolate Land Volcarona to get it in safely against the opposing team and start punching holes in defensive cores. Slither Wing tends to invite in Fire-types onto the field, so fire resistant teammates such as Garchomp and Garganacl are appreciated.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Good natural bulk, useful defensive typing, and an excellent support movepool make Slither Wing a good mixed defense pivot that repeatedly pivots and most notably switches into Ground-types like Great Tusk. Regenerator makes the most of its pivoting ability, but Fur Coat and Unaware are options for greater bulk or deterring setup, respectively. Will-O-Wisp allows it to punish switch-ins like Iron Valiant and Iron Hands with a burn. Its massive Attack allows it to use STAB U-turn to maintain momentum while bringing in more offensive teammates like Chi-Yu and Iron Bundle. Even with investment, Slither Wing struggles to check certain physical attackers like Ceruledge and Dragonite, so Pokemon like Fur Coat Garganacl and Corviknight make good teammates. Slither Wing also has difficulty against Fairy- and Flying-types like Scream Tail and Noivern, so it appreciates teammates like Iron Moth and Garganacl that are able to handle them.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Iron Bundle, Dragapult, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Dragapult and Iron Valiant, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and can fire off Terrain-boosted Thunderbolts. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Regenerator Pivot
sets.description: RegenVest Iron Treads is a great specially defensive pivot and spinner. It is able to switch into prominent special attackers such as Gholdengo and threaten them out. Knock Off removes key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and deters spinblockers from switching in, and Volt Switch has excellent synergy with Regenerator. If its teammates already provide adequate entry hazard control, Iron Head and Ice Spinner are options to target Scream Tail and Dragonite, respectively. A Sassy nature with minimum Speed investment ensures the slowest possible pivot with Volt Switch. Iron Treads appreciates physically defensive teammates like Fur Coat Slowking, which can form a VoltTurn core to bring in powerful-but-frail teammates like Iron Bundle and Dragapult.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description:
• Freeze-Dry and Hydro Pump make Iron Bundle incredibly threatening with perfect coverage.
  • Taunt can be used to stop recovery and status attempts from walls like Corviknight, while Flip Turn can gain momentum. Encore is effective at PP stalling recovery attempts from Pokemon while also locking Pokemon into suboptimal moves like Stealth Rock to take advantage of.
  • Tera Ice boosts Freeze-Dry's and Ice Beam's power to high levels and also removes the neutrality to Freeze-Dry from opposing Iron Bundle, making a potential mirror match safer.
  • Tera Water Iron Bundle has immense power on Hydro Pump; Tera Water also removes its Fighting-type weakness and Fire-type neutrality, which helps against Choice Scarf Great Tusk and Koraidon trying to revenge kill it.
  • Iron Bundle has to use its high Speed to force out frail Pokemon or force defensive Terastallization, both of which it can take advantage of.
  • Getting Iron Bundle safe switch-ins on defensive Pokemon that are threatened by Hydro Pump is the best way to use its offensive capabilities, allowing for defensive answers to be Taunted or pivoted on to wear down opposing teams.
  • Pelipper and Miraidon are strong teammates for Iron Bundle, providing rain and Electric Terrain support to power it up.
  • Entry hazard setters are also very strong, since Iron Bundle appreciates checks like Corviknight and Annihilape being worn down. It also can use Taunt to stop Defog Corviknight and pressure the premier spinners in Great Tusk and Iron Treads.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Bundle is a terrifying wallbreaker with incredible Speed and unresisted STAB coverage. Primordial Sea counters Desolate Land and allows Hydro Pump to OHKO most non-Ice Scales foes, while Mold Breaker breaks through walls like Ice Scales Corviknight. For the last slot, U-turn is used to pivot against Water-immune foes like Desolate Land Volcarona, while Flip Turn hits Pokemon like Ice Scales Blissey and Corviknight harder. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight help Iron Bundle safely switch into and pressure threats like Chi-Yu and Iron Moth. Strong physical attackers like Baxcalibur and Great Tusk are also good teammates, as Iron Bundle often forces in specially defensive walls that these Pokemon can threaten; Rapid Spin Great Tusk can also double as entry hazard removal. Pokemon who can set entry hazards like Ting-Lu and Garchomp are great partners for Iron Bundle, as they help it wear down its checks faster.

sets.name: Magic Guard Disrupter
sets.description: In addition to its strong wallbreaking capabilities, Iron Bundle's immense Speed allows it to outspeed almost the entire unboosted metagame and utilize Encore or Taunt to serve as a disrupter, hindering setup sweepers like Nasty Plot Gholdengo and passive Pokemon like Clodsire. Encore punishes setup sweepers and can burn extra recovery PP from opposing walls, while Taunt denies recovery in the first place. U-turn allows Iron Bundle to escape from dangerous switch-ins like Desolate Land Iron Moth while maintaining momentum, and Magic Guard keeps it from getting worn down by entry hazards through repeated switches. Iron Bundle struggles against specially defensive Pokemon like Florges and Blissey, so it pairs well with physically offensive teammates like Kingambit and Ceruledge. Iron Bundle also has low Special Defense, so it appreciates teammates like Ice Scales Corviknight and Clodsire that can take special attacks well.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: A huge HP stat and STAB Volt Switch make RegenVest Iron Hands a valuable specially defensive pivot that can switch into threats like Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and Chi-Yu. Aside from dissuading Flying-types like Dragonite and Noivern from switching into it, Ice Punch significantly harms Ground-types like Garchomp and Clodsire, allowing Iron Hands to pivot more freely with Volt Switch. Special wallbreakers like Iron Bundle and Noivern form a VoltTurn core with Iron Hands, and they appreciate being brought in on physical walls like Avalugg and Scream Tail via its Volt Switch. Corviknight can remove entry hazards, which would prevent Iron Hands from freely pivoting, with Defog and check threats like Iron Valiant and Great Tusk for it. Minimum Speed investment allows Iron Hands to pull off slow pivots for frail offensive teammates.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fur Coat Iron Hands uses its titanic bulk to check prominent attackers like Ceruledge and Kingambit while its solid Attack and Swords Dance prevent it from being passive. Drain Punch provides much-needed recovery as well as threatens Pokemon like Blissey and Cyclizar. Thunder Punch hits Fighting-resistant foes like Iron Moth and Iron Valiant, while Ice Punch covers Pokemon like Dragonite and Garchomp. Earthquake provides coverage for Pokemon like Clodsire that Iron Hands would otherwise struggle against. Iron Hands can also use Volt Switch alongside its low Speed to serve as a bulky slow pivot to safely bring in frail offensive teammates like Iron Valiant and Iron Bundle. Because of its below average Special Defense, Iron Hands pairs well with specially defensive teammates like Blissey and Ice Scales Corviknight. Iron Hands also struggles against Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Scream Tail, so it appreciates teammates like Gholdengo and Iron Moth that can take them on.

sets.name: Triage
sets.description: Iron Hands is the premier Belly Drum + Triage user thanks to its excellent bulk, Attack and STAB Drain Punch. With a free turn of setup, it can sweep frailer teams or clean up weakened balance teams. Ice Punch is a good coverage move to deal with threats such as Great Tusk and Hippowdon that otherwise can check it, while Earthquake is another coverage option that can better deal with Fur Coat Gholdengo. The 132 Speed EVs outpace Skeledirge, which would otherwise check Iron Hands with Will-O-Wisp. Frailer offensive teammates such as Iron Moth and Dragapult appreciate Iron Hands's ability to break through their common checks such as Garganacl and Ice Scales Corviknight. Iron Hands appreciates being brought in safely by slow pivots like Corviknight or by Shed Tail Cyclizar. Iron Hands can also have a tough time dealing with Fur Coat and Unaware walls like Hippowdon, so pairing it with a strong special attacker like Iron Bundle to deal with them is recommended.

sets.name: Agility
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Iron Moth is a powerful special attacker that also provides good defensive utility thanks to Desolate Land and Morning Sun. Its near-unique offensive typing lets it threaten common walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and Scream Tail, especially when boosted by sun. U-turn can be used to maintain momentum against predicted switch-ins like Garchomp and Garganacl, while Toxic Spikes punishes switch-ins with status. Iron Moth complements Ice Scales Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their vulnerability to Iron Bundle. Pokemon like Dragapult and Dragonite appreciate Iron Moth taking advantage of their Steel-type checks like Corviknight.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Specially defensive Iron Moth uses its solid bulk, good defensive typing, and sun-boosted Morning Sun to consistently check foes like Iron Bundle, Volcarona, and some Iron Valiant variants. It's not entirely passive either, as the boosts from Fiery Dance under sun allow it to eventually overwhelm passive foes like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Florges. U-turn lets it gain momentum by pivoting out safely, and Toxic Spikes punishes grounded foes like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Iron Hands. Due to its devastating Ground weakness, Ground-immune Pokemon like Corviknight and Dragonite make good pairings with it. Iron Moth works well with wallbreakers like Great Tusk and Iron Bundle, as they appreciate being given free entry to threaten its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Iron Moth is a great complement to common special walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers several of their weaknesses like Iron Bundle and Volcarona.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
• With good bulk, an immunity to burn, and just enough Speed to work, Baxcalibur is a powerful Dragon Dance sweeper.

  • Icicle Spear KOes Breloom and Mimikyu through Focus Sash and Disguise respectively.

  • While Glaive Rush is valuable for late-game sweeping, it does make Baxcalibur very vulnerable to bulky OHKO move users such as Dondozo and Garganacl.

  • Alternatively, Ice Shard means Baxcalibur will have a difficult time breaking past bulky Steel-types early-game, but it makes it an effective cleaner otherwise.

Tera Types

  • Dragon: This makes Glaive Rush deal obscene damage and removes weaknesses to Mach Punch and Bullet Punch.

  • Electric: When paired with Tera Blast, this is Life Orb Baxcalibur's best shot at dealing damage to Dondozo switch-ins. The paralysis immunity also helps Baxcalibur set up against Chansey with less risk.

  • Steel: With a Tera type of Steel, Baxcalibur can set up on Mimikyu and Dragon-type attacks.

Items

  • Life Orb: This helps Baxcalibur sweep reliably and ensures Icicle Spear OHKOes Breloom through Focus Sash.

  • Loaded Dice: With a guaranteed 4 hits from Icicle Spear, Baxcalibur is able to always OHKO offensive Mimikyu after Dragon Dance.

sets.name: Bulky Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Baxcalibur's bulk and the wonderful Ice Shard make it a good user of Assault Vest, making it especially effective against the Rotom formes.

  • Icicle Spear is recommended despite its inconsistent damage, as it deals damage through Mimikyu's disguise and potentially KOes Focus Sash users like Breloom and Meowscarada.

  • Glaive Rush makes Baxcalibur very vulnerable to getting KOed the next turn, but it is still the least risky Dragon-type STAB move. Remember that Ice Shard will remove Glaive Rush's negative effects as well.

  • A Ground Tera type gives Baxcalibur a reliable STAB move in Earthquake, resistance to Stealth Rock, and removes a ton of weaknesses, all at the cost of losing to Water-types such as Rotom-W.

EV Spreads

  • 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Spe with Adamant: This simple EV spread maximizes Baxcalibur's bulk and power.

  • 116 HP / 252 Atk / 140 Spe with Jolly: The Speed investment here outspeeds Modest Gholdengo and Adamant Dragonite.

sets.name: Air Balloon
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

battlestadiumsingles.overview:
Welcome to the next generation of Battle Stadium Singles! In this new and exciting metagame, new ideas are constantly developing, so this analysis will constantly be updated to reflect metagame trends.

If you feel this analysis is not up to date, feel free to check out the thread for this Pokemon and post suggestions. For more resources on Series 1 in general, check out this thread.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description:
• With Trick and an immunity to status moves, Gholdengo is a dangerous Choice item attacker for offensive and stall teams alike!

  • Thunderbolt 2HKOes Dondozo and deals serious damage to Tera Flying Garganacl.

  • Dazzling Gleam deals massive damage to Meowscarada and Hydreigon.

  • Nasty Plot can be used to give Gholdengo more bite against defensive, slower teams after using Trick.

  • Focus Blast is an option to ruin Kingambit, though its accuracy can be an issue.

  • Use a neutral nature Gholdengo that has a Timid Mint used on it. This way, Gholdengo can eat any Berry without being confused after Trick.

Tera Types

  • Flying: With a Flying Tera type, Gholdengo gains an extremely useful immunity to Ground, which is especially useful on Choice Specs sets and against users of Fissure such as Dondozo.

  • Ghost: The extra damage from Shadow Ball can make Gholdengo a more effective late-game cleaner.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting gives Gholdengo a far better chance of defeating Kingambit.

  • Water: In addition to giving Gholdengo a valuable resistance to Fire, this makes Gholdengo deal much more damage to Volcarona and common Tera Fire users such as Dragapult.

  • Steel: Make It Rain becomes very powerful with a Tera boost, at the cost of making Gholdengo vulnerable to Mach Punch from Breloom.

  • Normal: A Normal Tera type gives Gholdengo the edge against opposing Ghost-types, at the cost of becoming very vulnerable to Breloom.

Items

  • Choice Scarf: With this, Gholdengo outspeeds key threats such as Dragapult, Meowscarada, and Hydreigon.

  • Choice Specs: Choice Specs make Gholdengo much more difficult to wall, with foes such as Dondozo getting 2HKOed.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot makes Gholdengo a terror against slower teams, especially with its good bulk, unpredictable coverage, and diverse Tera Types.

  • Substitute lets Gholdengo avoid residual damage from Garganacl's Salt Cure and ease prediction in general.

  • Psyshock lets Gholdengo break through Chansey and Clodsire more easily.

  • Despite its reliability issues, Focus Blast lets Gholdengo defeat Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Flying: Flying Gholdengo gets the jump on dangerous Earthquake users such as Garchomp and Dragonite.

  • Fighting: With Tera Fighting, Kingambit is unlikely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping.

  • Water: With this Tera type, Volcarona and Skeledirge are far less likely to stop Gholdengo from sweeping.

  • Normal: While it's a much worse defensive typing, Tera Normal does let Gholdengo surprise faster Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Dragapult, at the cost of being weak to Mach Punch.

Items

  • Leftovers: This is the most reliable option for keeping Gholdengo healthy and pairs especially well with Substitute.

  • Covert Cloak: Covert Cloak prevents Salt Cure from chipping down Gholdengo, making it far easier for it to run Recover against Garganacl.

  • Air Balloon: Air Balloon ruins Breloom's chances of winning the lead war against Gholdengo and makes Hippowdon easy setup bait.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: This set has no write-up in progress yet. If you have experience with this set, feel free to reserve it here.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Gholdengo's good bulk and unpredictable Tera types make it a great user of Assault Vest.

  • Dazzling Gleam punishes Dark-type revenge killers such as Hydreigon and Meowscarada when combined with Tera.

  • Thunderbolt is Gholdengo's best shot at muscling past Dondozo and also deals good damage to Corviknight and Tera Flying Garganacl.

  • Focus Blast is Gholdengo's best hope of getting past Kingambit.

Tera Types

  • Flying: A Flying-type makes Gholdengo much more difficult to revenge kill with common Earthquake users such as Garchomp and Dragonite.

  • Fighting: Tera Fighting is Gholdengo's best chance of breaking past Kingambit.

  • Water: With Assault Vest, Gholdengo can tank most Fire-type attacks against it and deal good damage to Volcarona. Watch out for its Giga Drain after Quiver Dance, though.

  • Normal: With a Normal Tera type, Gholdengo can defeat several faster Ghost-types such as Dragapult and Mimikyu, at the cost of a worse defensive typing and losing to Breloom.

vgc2023.overview:
• Gholdengo is one of Series 1's most threatening special attackers, with a base 133 Special Attack stat and exclusive access to Make It Rain.

  • Good as Gold gives Gholdengo immunities to some of the metagame's most disruptive support moves, including Amoonguss's Spore and Grimmsnarl's Parting Shot.

  • Gholdengo is lacking in Speed, making Tailwind users such as Murkrow, Hydreigon, and Talonflame great partners. Murkrow, in particular, is a great partner thanks to Haze undoing Special Attack drops from Make It Rain.

  • Gholdengo often struggles against faster, hard-hitting Pokemon such as Garchomp and Hydreigon, making partners such as Sylveon valuable.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description:
• Make It Rain and Shadow Ball let Gholdengo take out a wide array of common Pokemon such as Armarouge, Annihilape and Sylveon.

  • Dazzling Gleam allows Gholdengo to fight back against the likes of Hydreigon.

  • Thunderbolt threatens to OHKO the likes of Gyarados and Palafin when equipped with Choice Specs. Trick is a good alternative option to lock Pokemon into undesirable moves, such as Indeedee-F into Trick Room.

  • Choice Specs makes Gholdengo one of the most threatening special attackers in the entire metagame. Choice Scarf lets Gholdengo outspeed Meowscarada, Garchomp, and Dragapult with a Timid nature, which it would otherwise need additional speed control to beat.

  • Steel is Gholdengo's preferred Tera type, boosting the damage output of Make It Rain even further and letting it OHKO Garchomp with ease.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Nasty Plot allows Gholdengo to secure OHKOs on just about everything weak to it, notably OHKOing specially defensive Amoonguss when Choice Specs would fail to.

  • Life Orb is the primary item used by Nasty Plot Gholdengo, boosting its damage at the cost of recoil. Metal Coat is a recoil-free way of boosting Gholdengo's primary move, Make It Rain. Air Balloon is an option to remove Gholdengo's Ground weakness, helping it match up better into the likes of Garchomp and RestTalk Dondozo.

  • Steel is Gholdengo's preferred Tera type, boosting Make It Rain's damage and removing crucial weaknesses to Dark-types. Tera Flying is an alternative that removes Gholdengo's Ground weakness without using an item, making it a great partner for Earthquake Garchomp.

sets.name: Defensive Nasty Plot
sets.description: Gholdengo's incredible typing, great stats, and setup potential make it a potent wincon with plenty of defensive utility. With Fur Coat-boosted bulk or the immunity granted by Earth Eater or Well-Baked Body, Gholdengo can switch into foes like Aerilate Dragonite, Iron Moth, and Clodsire and can set up with Nasty Plot to wallbreak. Earth Eater and Well-Baked Body may also surprise the opponent, allowing Gholdengo to set up in key situations and gain a winning advantage. Alternatively, a set with Hex + Thunder Wave + Substitute lets Gholdengo make the most of advantageous situations and avoid having to switch out as often. To dually punish switches and remain healthy, Gholdengo should be paired with teammates that can set entry hazards and provide Defog support, like Ting-Lu and Ice Scales Corviknight, respectively. For immediate power, wallbreakers like Sheer Force Dragapult and Iron Valiant and Choice Band Baxcalibur and Great Tusk are excellent partners. Dragapult is a notably good partner, as it shares the same checks with Gholdengo, forming a core that can overload most special walls.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description: Choice item Gholdengo uses its excellent typing and stats to frustrate offensive teams and Trick to cripple its defensive checks. Choice Scarf outspeeds key threats like Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and +1 Dragonite and neutral natured Baxcalibur, while Choice Specs puts more pressure on defensive teams. Regenerator allows Gholdengo to function as an offensive pivot and repeatedly check foes like Baxcalibur, while Good as Gold deters Defog attempts from Corviknight. Trick cripples most walls—such as Corviknight— by giving them a Choice Scarf or Choice Specs, making them much less effective at doing their jobs. Nasty Plot is a great option after using Trick, while Recover fits on the Good as Gold and Earth Eater variants. Gholdengo finds itself at home on balance and offense teams that can utilize its many helpful traits, such as preventing Defog and crippling specially defensive walls. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu pair well with Gholdengo, and other special attackers like Iron Bundle and Dragapult capitalize on Gholdengo taking out the opposing walls.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
• Icicle Crash 2HKOes Corviknight and avoids Rocky Helmet, while Ice Spinner is more accurate and has the bonus of removing Electric Terrain.
  • Sacred Sword hits checks such as Kingambit and opposing Chien-Pao. Another option is to run a double priority combination with Ice Shard and Sucker Punch. Sucker Punch hits very crucial Pokemon that Ice Shard can't, such as Tera Fire Koraidon, Tera Fire Flutter Mane, and Iron Bundle.
  • An Adamant nature allows Chien-Pao to achieve ridiculous feats such as revenge killing Flutter Mane from 90% HP with Ice Shard. A Jolly nature lets Chien-Pao Speed tie with Koraidon, Miraidon, opposing Jolly Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane, giving Chien-Pao the freedom to click its strongest moves less reluctantly.
  • Tera Dark allows Chien-Pao to 2HKO the entire tier while letting it still switch into weaker moves such as Shadow Ball. Tera Ice gives Chien-Pao the ability to OHKO Flutter Mane with Ice Shard, making it a terrific late-game cleaner.
  • Choice Band Chien-Pao is a wallbreaker that is best suited for bulky offense structures that love its revenge killing and wallbreaking capabilities.
  • Pokemon like Iron Treads, Hatterene, and Koraidon, which can provide entry hazard control or pivoting, are excellent teammates for Chien-Pao.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its high Speed and decent STAB coverage that hits common Fur Coat users like Gholdengo and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster offensive threats such as Iron Bundle and Dragapult; alternatively, Ice Shard is weaker but hits Roaring Moon super effectively. Sacred Sword beats Steel-types like Kingambit and bypasses Garganacl's Defense boosts. Sword of Ruin is its most powerful offensive ability, while Mold Breaker is more efficient at dismantling Fur Coat walls. Chien-Pao's best fit is on balance teams that can provide it with safe switch-ins and take advantage of the holes it creates. Iron Valiant and Ceruledge are recommended teammates, as both can help Chien-Pao beat the incredibly troublesome Dondozo and Toxapex. Corviknight and Iron Treads are both good teammates thanks to their ability to pivot Chien-Pao in safely, in addition to clearing Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
• Ting-Lu is a key Pokemon for many playstyles in SV Ubers, ranging from stall to bulky offense.
  • Whirlwind helps Ting-Lu against Substitute users like Flutter Mane and Baxcalibur and other threatening hyper offense Pokemon such as Agility + Calm Mind Miraidon.
  • Tera Steel lets Ting-Lu check Pokemon such as Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Bundle. Tera Ghost, on the other hand, lets Ting-Lu soft check physical attackers such as Great Tusk, Koraidon locked into Close Combat, Iron Hands, and Iron Valiant. Tera Fire is another option that lets Ting-Lu soft check and beat Chi-Yu one-on-one. Lasty, Tera Fairy is also an option to check Dragon-types and have an overall good defensive typing against Pokemon that would normally overwhelm Ting-Lu, such as Choice Specs Miraidon.
  • Ting-Lu works best as a defensive pivot on bulky offense teams, capitalizing on its massive natural bulk and ability Vessel of Ruin to set Spikes against Pokemon like Miraidon and Chi-Yu, tank big hits, and recover HP with Protect.
  • Pokemon that appreciate Ting-Lu's ability to wear down opposing Ground-types with Spikes, such as Miraidon and Koraidon, are excellent partners for it. Other defensive Pokemon such as Iron Treads, Corviknight, and Blissey relieve pressure of Ting-Lu by helping to check Miraidon; they also check Flutter Mane, and Corviknight additionally helps check Chien-Pao.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: RegenVest Ting-Lu is a reliable special wall and a premier Miraidon check. Regenerator gives Ting-Lu reliable recovery without conflicting with Assault Vest. Nuzzle discourages dangerous attackers like Zacian-C and Palkia-O from switching in. U-turn allows Ting-Lu to safely bring in teammates thanks to its low Speed. Ceaseless Edge forces chip damage on foes, letting offensive teammates wallbreak more easily. Knock Off removes items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Covert Cloak, making Ting-Lu's own utility more effective; it also punishes Imposter users attempting to gain Regenerator. Ting-Lu fits best on balance teams, which appreciate its ability to spread paralysis and safely bring in teammates thanks to its huge bulk. Dangerous wallbreakers like Miraidon, Zacian-C, and Palkia-O help maximize the effectiveness of U-turn pivoting. Ting-Lu is unable to naturally check Palkia-O and Quiver Dance Arceus-Water, so a teammate that helps shore up this weakness, such as Arceus-Grass or Hisuian Goodra, is appreciated. Tera Fairy provides an immunity to Dragon, allowing Ting-Lu to block Dragon Energy from Palkia-O and Choice Specs Miraidon; alternatively, Tera Grass provides a Water resistance, covering for Palkia-O's Water Spout and coverage from Miraidon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, Dragapult, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Dragonite and Noivern, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Dragonite, Fur Coat Iron Hands, and Earth Eater Gholdengo. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail, Iron Valiant, and Iron Bundle can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Ice Scales Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good teammates; the former also provides Defog, while the latter provides Toxic Spikes to amplify Ting-Lu's own entry hazards.

sets.name: RegenVest Wall
sets.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Dragapult, Iron Moth and Gholdengo. Throat Chop lets it beat all Boomburst users and Ground-immune Gholdengo. Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon or Blissey. Some special attackers like Iron Valiant and Iron Bundle can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Ice Scales Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main Fur Coat wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce its weakness to entry hazards.

sets.name: Choice Item
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO Ice Scales Corviknight and physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Dragapult and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Ice Scales Corviknight, Garganacl, and Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Iron Hands make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Roaring Moon's Dragon / Dark typing and high special bulk enable it to switch into Gholdengo, Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and other special attackers, setting it apart from other offensive pivots like Iron Bundle and Iron Moth. Earthquake forces out Ground-weak Pokemon like Iron Moth and Kingambit. Iron Head and Stone Edge target Florges and Iron Bundle, respectively. 112 EVs in Attack let Roaring Moon always OHKO Dragapult with Throat Chop. Roaring Moon fits best on teams in need of a pivot with both longevity and a Speed tier that exceeds the likes of Iron Bundle and Dragapult. Roaring Moon struggles to break past physically defensive foes like Great Tusk and Iron Hands, so it appreciates having strong special attackers such as Armarouge and Iron Valiant as teammates. Steel-types like Corviknight and physical walls like Iron Hands are great for patching up Roaring Moon's defensive blind spots.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Sheer Force
sets.description: Iron Valiant's great offensive stats and wide movepool make it a great Sheer Force wallbreaker. Its coverage is almost perfect: barring the use of abilities that provide an immunity to Iron Valiant's attacks, Corviknight, Skeledirge, Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Clodsire are all at risk of being OHKOed or 2HKOed after minor chip damage. To more reliably defeat Ghost-types, Iron Valiant can even run Shadow Ball instead of Thunderbolt or Knock Off over Psychic-type coverage. A Naive nature is used to maximize the amount of targets Iron Valiant outspeeds, such as Iron Moth, Iron Treads, and Garchomp. Iron Valiant fits best on balance teams that appreciate its ability to pave the way for other dangerous attackers like Dragapult and Great Tusk. Iron Valiant appreciates allies that can keep the field clear of entry hazards, such as Corviknight and Avalugg, and also switch in on dangerous priority like Dragonite's Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Oh no it can switch moves
Choice Band
sets.description: This is a sample set before we work on new analyses. These will update as the metagame continues to develop. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
• Electric- and Dragon-type STAB moves allow Miraidon to force out a large portion of the metagame and gain momentum by pivoting with U-turn.
  • Tera Blast with Tera Water targets Ground-types that resist Electro Drift and would take advantage of a Draco Meteor Special Attack drop, such as Ting-Lu and Iron Treads.
  • Overheat can instead be used to beat Iron Treads without needing to Terastallize.
  • Among its viable Tera types, Water is also Miraidon's best bet defensively, removing its weaknesses to Dragon- and Fairy-type moves and resisting Steel-type moves from Gholdengo and Iron Treads. Tera Dragon is used with Overheat, powering up Draco Meteor when Tera Blast isn't run.
  • Pivot Miraidon should be used aggressively, taking advantage of its high Special Attack to force out foes and use U-turn, wearing down its most common checks like Ting-Lu.
  • When a team is sufficiently worn down, Miraidon can use Electro Drift and Tera Blast or Draco Meteor to clean thanks to its high Speed.
  • Entry hazard setters are greatly appreciated, especially Spikes setters, to help wear down Ground-types for Miraidon. Ting-Lu, Great Tusk, and Clodsire can all set hazards.
  • Tera Water Miraidon appreciates Pelipper setting rain to power up Tera Blast, and Pelipper also checks physical Choice Scarf users like Koraidon and Great Tusk, which can revenge kill Miraidon. Tera Dragon Miraidon instead prefers support from Koraidon to power up Overheat, and it usually appreciates Koriadon running Choice Scarf to revenge kill foes.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Miraidon is a fierce wallbreaker that can reliably threaten nearly the entire tier with its lethal offensive typing. Volt Switch helps maintain momentum and can scout opposing Terastallization. Trick ruins Ice Scales users like Hisuian Goodra and Arceus-Grass lacking a held Plate, and Steam Eruption threatens burns and targets Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Clodsire; Grass Knot hits many of the same targets but makes Miraidon easier to Imposter-proof. Miraidon's massive damage potential and ability to break down defensive cores makes it an excellent fit on offense. Palkia-O and Final Gambit Eternatus make good partners, as they can help remove Ground-types and weaken special walls with Dragon Energy. Terastallizing into one of its original types is useful to supercharge Miraidon's damage output; however, Tera Steel can be useful to get a surprise KO on Zacian-C, and Tera Fairy is useful for blanking an Imposter user's Dragon Energy. Imposter-proofing is generally done with a specially defensive Ground-type teammate like Ting-Lu or Groudon.

sets.name: Setup Sweeper
sets.description: Miraidon's typing and good stats make it a potent setup sweeper. Nasty Plot provides higher immediate power, whereas Quiver Dance makes setting up easier, enables the use of a Modest nature, and allows Miraidon to outspeed and threaten Zacian-C. Draco Plate + Judgment is used so Miraidon can fully self Imposter-proof, in addition to being usable at low HP, unlike Dragon Energy. Miraidon's best fit is on bulky teams that appreciate its instant damage output, potential to sweep, on top of its innate self-Imposter-proofing and good matchup into common Prankster users. Teammates that can help destroy Ice Scales users, such as Final Gambit Eternatus and Poison Heal Arceus-Fairy are appreciated, the latter of which can also absorb Knock Off. Miraidon should be careful when Terastallizing, as this removes its 4x Electric-type resistance and makes it more vulnerable to being PP stalled by Imposter; however, Tera Electric or Tera Dragon are useful for damage output, and Nasty Plot sets enjoy having Tera Steel for Zacian-C.
